narrative.title: V Corps - 1943Q1
narrative.situation: British Corps (Mixed Infantry and Armoured) deployed in North Africa during 1943Q1.
narrative.objectives: V Corps was First Army's primary offensive formation in northern Tunisia during Q1 1943. Mission: advance eastward from Medjez el Bab toward Tunis through difficult hill country. Operations focused on seizing key terrain (djebels) dominating valleys and roads. Limited by terrain, weather, and logistics during Q1 1943 - offensive operations constrained to February's Operation Ochsenkopf (German counterattack, defended successfully) and March preparations for spring offensive. Corps held defensive positions during worst winter weather (January-February), then prepared for April offensive operations.
narrative.axis_objective: Hold current positions and prevent Allied breakthrough.
narrative.allied_objective: Advance and neutralize Axis defensive positions.

weather.terrain: Northern Tunisia hill country and valleys. Tebourba-Medjez el Bab sector features: steep hills (djebels) with narrow valleys, limited road network, easily defended terrain favoring defenders. Extensive olive groves and agricultural areas. Rivers and wadis prone to flooding during winter rains. Terrain channelizes movement, limiting armor employment. Mud severely restricted off-road movement during Q1 1943.
environmental_challenges: Mud - roads and tracks impassable during heavy rains, limiting mobility
Limited road network - few all-weather roads, easy for enemy to block key routes
Mountainous terrain - restricts armor employment, favors infantry and artillery
River crossings - wadis flooded during rains, bridges critical chokepoints
Supply difficulties - extended lines from Algiers through mountains
Cold wet weather - health issues (trench foot, respiratory infections)
Limited observation - hilly terrain creates dead zones for artillery observers

air_support.note: No theater air summary available for this quarter

special_rules: Mixed arms coordination - infantry and armour working together in restricted terrain
Defensive expertise - held against German Operation Ochsenkopf counterattack
All-arms cooperation - British divisions, US CCB, Commandos, Paratroops
Mountain warfare adaptation - infantry-artillery coordination in hills
Experienced leadership - Allfrey, Evelegh, Keightley veteran commanders
